node.title: Mathematics and Statistics skills and careers
node.description: Skills, career opportunities and employment related to study of mathematics and statistics
node.keywords: maths and stats, maths, stats, statistics, skills

primary.introduction_text: Mathematics and Statistics skills are indispensable problem-solving and decision-making tools at the heart of advances in many areas of life. Opportunities for graduates and postgraduates are available throughout industry and commerce.

rich_text_content.text: Skills you can develop

As well as the specific knowledge gained from studying for an OU degree, you'll develop many transferable and work-related skills that are highly valued by employers and which will increase your employability.
For Mathematics and Statistics students the employability skills you will develop include the ability to:
use mathematics and statistics to help develop solutions to practical problems
follow complex mathematical and statistical arguments and to develop brief arguments of your own
work with mathematical and statistical computer software packages
find, extract and analyse data from many sources
communicate mathematical and statistical information effectively
manage your time and employ good organisational skills
work with patience and persistence.
To see specific learning outcomes related to the degrees in this area have a look at OU Mathematics and Statistics Courses.
To check which skills valued by employers can be developed from studying a particular subject, look at the 'What can I do with my degree' pages on the Prospects website.

The OU Careers and Employability Services define student employability as: 'A set of capabilities and achievements that support students in developing their careers, raising their aspirations and enhancing their contribution to society'.

Whatever your motivations for study, your goals and career aspirations, you are entitled to supported personal development planning either as an intrinsic part of your programme of study or through signposted optional activities. You can view our full Student Employability Policy Statement on our website.
If you’re a registered OU student you can find further careers information tailored to your qualification at your Study Home site under the Succeed tab.

node.title: Working with images in your documents
node.description: Guidance on resizing images to reduce file size.
node.keywords: resize, online, format, jpeg, png, file size, images, pictures

rich_text_content.text: When you’re preparing an assignment, it's important to be aware of the file size of the document. For submission using the online submission system a single file should be no larger than 10MB unless your module tells you otherwise. If you've included images in your document, they can take up a lot of the file size. If you need to, you can reduce the file size of images to reduce the overall document file size.

File size is different to how big the image looks on the page. If you reduce the size of the picture box in your Word document it won’t change the file size. The easiest way to reduce the file size is to reduce the resolution of the image. An image that was originally prepared for print will be of a higher resolution which is not necessary for your assignments.

You can check the file size of an image by opening the folder you've stored the image in and right-clicking on the image name and selecting Properties from the list (on a Mac you'll need the Get Info window).
It also helps if you save images in the best format before you insert them into your document.
JPEG format for photos.
PNG format for screenshots or diagrams.
You'll need to find the advice on how to reduce the file size of an image for the word processing software you're using. Use these links for information on the most common word processing packages.

node.title: Setting up separate accounts on your computer
node.description: The benefits of a separate account for study on your computer

primary.introduction_text: This article describes the benefits of separate accounts on your computer, but doesn't go into details about how to set them up. The procedures vary between versions of operating systems and we provide useful links at the foot of this article to help you.

rich_text_content.text: Many people share their computer with family members or work colleagues. Fortunately, modern operating systems make it easy for each person to have their own private space on the computer so that there's no mixing up of files and resources. Even if you have sole use of your computer there’s a case for maintaining more than one account.
Security, peace of mind and greater productivity

As a student working online, you'll invest many hours in gathering material, saving it, annotating it and writing about it. You can safeguard that work by preventing any interference, intentional or otherwise, by other people. With your own account, protected with a private password, you get peace of mind.
There’s also a worthwhile boost in productivity because everything is where you left it when you last used the computer.
The list of recently used files in the word processor is the list of files you last used, not those that other people used.
Your email program contains only your accounts and you can quickly see what’s new and important.
You can set up rules in email to process your incoming post without it tangling with other people’s post.
Your bookmarks and browsing history are as you left them and don't include other's browsing history.
Reduce distractions with a study-only account

It's a recognised characteristic of online study that the distractions of the wider internet can draw attention away from the business of learning. If you waste time on distractions you might want to consider setting up a study-only account. It isn’t for everybody but it can really benefit your concentration.

You set up a separate account as a non-administrator (Standard) account that limits the scope of what you can do. You can arrange to access only your OU-related email accounts, and all your browser bookmarks would be study related. You could even use the parental controls to block browser access to the most tempting websites and applications.
It’s the online equivalent of making a good working atmosphere in your place of study, with as few distractions as possible.
You can, of course, still get to all the distractions easily by signing out of your study account and in to your normal account.

node.title: Speak, don’t type: using speech to text
node.description: The accuracy of speech to text dictation means that it is now a viable alternative to typing. The implementations in Windows, Mac OS X, iOS and Android are introduced.
node.keywords: Recognition, Siri, dictate, Dragon, Windows, Mac OS X, iOS, Android, spoken, my computer my way, abilitynet

rich_text_content.text: Speech to text is a widely available function on PCs, Macs and mobile devices. People who find typing slow, difficult or impossible, can benefit from using speech to text technology.

Most computers will come with a built in microphone. However, if yours doesn't or you're not getting good results using the built in microphone for dictation, you can get an external microphone. These are inexpensive and easy to install. Headsets also work well with dictation programmes.

A headset is a good idea if you're studying in an area with a lot of background noise as it holds the microphone close to your lips thereby reducing any background noise. The dictation software will cope with measured, well enunciated speech; try not to speak too quickly. You don't have to train the software to learn your particular voice.
Dictation software can do two things:
Control your computer – opening and closing programmes, selecting commands from menus and so on.
Dictate text into a document.
Both types of functionality have a set of commands and conventions that have to be learned. Most will require internet access to process the information.
AbilityNet Talking to your device has information on talking to your mobile or tablet, both iOS and Android, and talking to your computer.

node.title: Evaluating websites and content
node.description: Criteria for judging the reliability of information you find on the web
node.keywords: Google, Bing, Duckduckgo, Yahoo, Jeeves, search tools, effective search, advanced search,

rich_text_content.text: It’s easy enough to find information online, but it’s sometimes harder to assess whether it’s reliable, current, or correct. Anyone can write anything they want, and can claim to be anyone they like.
There are three simple questions to ask yourself to help you to work out whether you want to rely on the information it contains.

Who is the author? – Try to find some information on the site that tells you who the author is. This could be in an 'About us' section, or in the contact details. Does the author have some authority in terms of the information on a site? Check that the site content is objective and that it is not biased to one particular viewpoint.
Do the aims of the site match the content? – If the site does present biased information often the author will explain why, and this may help you assess the reliability of the information.
When was the content produced? – Look when it was last updated.

For an introduction to skills for working online take a look at the Library's Being digital website. It contains a collection of short, easy to follow activities covering the skills needed to be effective online, including evaluating and trusting online content.

node.title: Setting up bookmarks in your browser
node.description: How to bookmark websites and keep track of your bookmarks.
node.keywords: Favourites, favorites, bookmarking a page, organising bookmarks, bookmark folder

rich_text_content.text: A bookmark is a handy link to take you back to a web page you’ve previously visited.

To make a bookmark of the page you’re on, press Ctrl + D (Cmd-D on a Mac). A box opens that gives a suggested name for the bookmark, usually the title of the page, which you can change. It also suggests the last folder you filed a bookmark into or you can select a different folder or set up a new folder.
Organising your bookmarks

It’s good to be organised with filing your bookmarks as it’s very difficult to find an individual bookmark within a massive list. Folders can be used to keep them organised, however the folders themselves need to be kept organised as well.
It’s well worth thinking of how you will file the bookmarks you’ve made for your Open University study so you can easily find them when needed.
You can search the internet to find ‘how to create bookmark folders’ for the latest instructions for your browser.

node.title: Your OU online appearance
node.description: How to change your appearance when you post to OU blogs and forums, etc.

rich_text_content.text: You have two types of OU profile:
your online appearance, which appears against your name when you post to OU forums, blogs and wikis.
and your administration profile, which contains your contact details for administrative purposes, described as your OU Profile in Student home in the Profile link.
To access either profile, click the Profile link in StudentHome.

If you have written something on your module website, for example in a forum, blog or wiki, you can also access your profile by clicking on the link to your name that is displayed next to your post, and then on Full profile.
Further information on how to manage your profile can be found in the Computing guide.
Default online appearance profile

Your default profile is visible to everyone in the OU and shows your name and a link to your personal blog. Sharing this information online is helpful, as it makes it easier for people to identify you. This basic information is taken from OU records and can't be amended on the profile pages.
Information on how to update your basic information (eg a change of surname due to marriage) can be found at Changing your name, password, address, etc..
Further information on correct use of your online profile can be found in the Student Computing Policy.

node.title: Reports
node.description: The different types of reports you may be asked to write and how may be structured.
node.keywords: Reports, report structure, how to write a report, how to draft a report

rich_text_content.text: Some modules ask students to produce reports. There are four main types of report:
information or description reports
reports of investigations or studies
maths reports
science reports.

These are composed of different sections, which can vary according to what is specified in your assignment or module guide. Always refer to your module materials to find out what sections might be required in your assignment.
The title of a report asks the question to be addressed and indicates the topic. Within the report itself you may need to incorporate the following sections.
Abstract
In a science or maths report this includes what was done, how it was done and what the main findings were. In an information report this is a short paragraph that summarises the main findings.
Introduction

In a maths report this outlines the aim of the report and gives essential background information, including the context where applicable, and defines key terms. In a science report this outlines the aim of the report and explains why the investigation was undertaken and places it in the context of previous work. In an information report this outlines the aim of the report and includes background information. It defines key terms and indicates how you approach the question. It might be appropriate to explain what you don't intend to write about – thus indicating the scope of your report.
Main body
This main section may also include sub-sections such as a discussion, results or findings, and the methodology. A maths report is likely to include sections in its main body on
modelling: the assumptions made, a description of the model including the choice of variables and parameters, the mathematics used and interpretation and evaluation of results
proofs: includes a statement of what is to be proved and details of the proof
history: includes a list of both supporting and opposing facts and then develops the argument.
In a science report the main body generally comprises
materials and methods: the experimental details
results: the results of the experiments performed. A commentary accompanies data presented in the form of graphs, tables, images or diagrams
discussion: a critical interpretation of the results presented in the context of other researchers' observations.

In an information report the main body should be divided into sections, possibly with sub-headings. Points can be numbered or presented in bullet form. Each point should be supported by evidence or an example.
Conclusions or recommendations

In a maths or science report this section may not be necessary, but could include suggestions for further research. In an information report this summarises (in one or two sentences) the main points of information.
Reference section
Check your module materials to see the format you need to use for the reference section.

node.title: When study gets difficult
node.description: How your friends and family can support you with your studies.

rich_text_content.text: All students have low points when they wonder why they started the module. Sometimes they just need a break and to forget about study for a while, or for someone to listen to their woes, but at other times they may need more.

OU students are often quite independent and don’t really want to ask for help, so the friends and family who know them best are very important in ensuring they are coping with their study and keeping things in perspective.

Your student’s OU tutor or study adviser is available to help with their difficulties relating to assignments, module materials and study skills. You could encourage your student to write down what is troubling them, to help get it clear, and to phone or email their tutor to talk it through. This is part of a tutor’s role and they are always happy to help.

Talking to other students on the module can be very reassuring for students feeling generally overwhelmed; others often have good tips for dealing with specific problems too. Online forum discussions can help them see that many fellow students have very similar difficulties, so even if time is tight it is worthwhile taking part. There are also useful online tips and resources in Study skills.

Anxieties about administrative matters such as fees, qualifications or arrangements for students with disabilities can also put pressure on study and motivation. OU advisers are available to give support – your student will have a contact number to call – or you could help them track down advice on the OU website.

Sometimes circumstances make it too difficult for a student to carry on with a particular module. OU staff know how painful it is to come to this decision and will help your student sort out the necessary administration. Encourage them to get in touch with whoever they know best – usually their tutor.
Some students share their experiences of how friends and family have helped in difficult times.
